headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: So my comment specifically around performance athletic is one that's, a, as a category, that is a category that's doing well just in end markets; and two, with regard to some of the sourcing region uncertainty that's out there, it's not a recent item, but
componenttext: So my comment specifically around performance athletic is one that's, a, as a category, that is a category that's doing well just in end markets; and two, with regard to some of the sourcing region uncertainty that's out there, it's not a recent item, but over time, they migrated more of their manufacturing outside of China already, so it's more of a relative comment from what we see. So that's what my comment was. And as far as what's going on, I think your second part of your question, Rosemarie, was around just the impact of migrating sourcing, this is something that can cause some near-term disruption in the industry related to some of the choppiness I noted. We are extremely well positioned for this given our global footprint that we have, our long experience of doing business in all the emerging markets where apparel is made, and so this is something that we see as an opportunity should things shift at a more accelerated pace.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: All right. And then I was wondering, you talked about the impact of the trade war on demands for retail apparel items. Looking at the fact that now, I believe, retailers are beginning to order for the holiday seasons, are you seeing a big change versus wh
componenttext: All right. And then I was wondering, you talked about the impact of the trade war on demands for retail apparel items. Looking at the fact that now, I believe, retailers are beginning to order for the holiday seasons, are you seeing a big change versus what was happening last year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: There's some of the uncertainty around it, for sure. I can't call one way or the other. And I will say, there's -- note, the tariffs aren't being implemented. So and there've been broad discussion about for the vast majority of apparel that there won't be
componenttext: There's some of the uncertainty around it, for sure. I can't call one way or the other. And I will say, there's -- note, the tariffs aren't being implemented. So and there've been broad discussion about for the vast majority of apparel that there won't be really an impact here. So I think this is overall had some, early on, we were thinking potential delays but just in general some of the choppiness that I've talked through. And if you look at just more broadly than that, China, the devaluation of the renminbi has actually made China cheaper to some retailers and brands as well in the meantime. So there's a number of factors that go into the decisions and we're just seeing general choppiness and it's too early for us to call.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited third quarter results. Please note that throughout today's discussion, we'll be making references to non-GAAP financial measures. The non-GAAP measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconc
componenttext: Thank you, Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited third quarter results. Please note that throughout today's discussion, we'll be making references to non-GAAP financial measures. The non-GAAP measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP on Pages A-4 and A-8 attached to the financial statements today's earnings release and appendix of our supplemental presentation materials. We remind you that we will make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These forward-looking statements are made subject to the safe harbor statement included in today's earnings release. On the call today are Mitch Butier, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Lovins, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. I'll now turn the call over to Mitch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, good day, everyone. We delivered solid profit growth in the third quarter, despite softer than usual market demand with EPS once again up double digits over prior year on a constant currency basis. Our focus in this slower growth environmen
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, good day, everyone. We delivered solid profit growth in the third quarter, despite softer than usual market demand with EPS once again up double digits over prior year on a constant currency basis. Our focus in this slower growth environment has been to protect even expand our margins in the base business, while driving faster-than-average growth in high-value categories, like RFID. We're executing well on both fronts. We appear to have recaptured most of the share we recently lost in LGM. Our intelligent labels platform continues to drive over 20% growth from RFID-enabled solutions, and IHM's commercial execution continues to improve. 
At the same time, our relentless focus on productivity was, again, a key driver of the margin expansion for the company this quarter. 
In sum, we are making good progress against our key strategic priorities and are on track to deliver our long-term financial targets. 
Label and Graphic Materials posted strong profitability on roughly a point of organic growth for the quarter, driven primarily by volume. High-value categories, again, grew faster than the base. 
As I mentioned, though all of the market data isn't in yet for the third quarter, we have good reason to believe that by the end of the quarter, we had recaptured the bulk of the share we at the tail of the inflationary cycle. 
In terms of global market trends, it appears that the soft market conditions that we saw in the first half of the year largely continued into the third quarter, with a modest improvement in Europe offset by a moderation of demand in South Asia.
Retail Branding and Information Solutions delivered solid organic growth driven by ongoing strength in RFID external embellishments, which more than offset declines in the base apparel business. 
As we mentioned in July, we saw trade-related uncertainty impacting orders in the second quarter. This uncertainty was reinforced when additional tariffs were announced in August. Now while trade-related issues are causing near-term uncertainty, we are well positioned in the base business given our global footprint and differentiated product and service capabilities. As for RFID, the growth trajectory continues to be resilient, with continued strength in apparel and even faster growth from other promising verticals though obviously off of a small base. Our total pipeline of customer engagements continue to expand, up more than 40% from just the beginning of this year, driven primarily by categories outside of apparel.
At the leader in ultrahigh frequency RFID, we are positioned extremely well to capture these opportunities, with industry-leading innovation and manufacturing capabilities and the best most experienced team in the space. We continue to increase our level of investment in business development and other resources to drive its growth as build out our Intelligent Labels platform to enable a future where every item can have a digital twin and digital life.
Industrial and Healthcare Materials sales growth was relatively strong on an organic basis due in part to slowdown in China's automotive market last year. That said, given the high proportion of this segment's portfolio that is focused on industrial and markets, I'm pleased with the solid top line performance the team delivered. And importantly, we made excellent progress in the quarter towards achieving our operating margin targets for the business.
In short another solid quarter overall in the midst of a challenging environment. Our strategy is to deliver outsized growth in high-value categories are working and our relentless focus on productivity continues to enable us to increase our pace of investment categories, increase our competitiveness overall and grow profitably in our base businesses while importantly, continuing to protect and expand operating margin. 
While we lowered the high end of our near-term outlook for top line growth due to recent market trends, and currently shift causes to reduce the high end of EPS guidance for the year, we are confident in our ability to achieve our long-term objectives, including GDP+ growth and top quartile returns. 
We will continue to seek opportunities to leverage our position of strength commercially, operationally and financially and as our hearts Amy before, but be prepared to lean forward as others may pull back. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and hello, everybody. As Mitch said, we delivered another solid quarter, with adjusted earnings per share of $1.66, up 14% despite the currency headwind. We grew sales by 2.1% on an organic basis, and currency translation reduced reported sales gr
componenttext:
Thanks, and hello, everybody. As Mitch said, we delivered another solid quarter, with adjusted earnings per share of $1.66, up 14% despite the currency headwind. We grew sales by 2.1% on an organic basis, and currency translation reduced reported sales growth by 2 points in the quarter. And our adjusted operating margin increased by a full point to 11.7%. 
We realized $18 million of restructuring savings net of transition costs in the quarter due in part to LGM's restructuring in the Europe that was largely completed as of the end of Q2. And our cash generation has been strong. We delivered $327 million of free cash flow year-to-date, up $67 million compared to the same period last year.
As we've discussed, we've increased our pace of fixed capital and IT-related spending for a few years to support our long-term organic growth and margin expansion plans with capital spending expected to be up by about $20 million this year. 
And we continue to return cash to shareholders. In the first 3 quarters of the year, we repurchased roughly 2 million shares at an aggregate cost of $204 million and paid $141 million in dividends for a total of $346 million of cash return to shareholders. Importantly, our balance sheet remains strong with net debt-to-adjusted-EBITDA taking down slightly in the quarter. Our current leverage position gives us ample capacity to continue executing our disciplined capital allocation strategy, including investing in organic growth and acquisitions while continuing to return cash to shareholders.
We are well positioned to take advantage of any dislocations in the market should they occur over the next few years. 
Turning to the segment results for the quarter. Label and Graphic Materials sales increased by 1.2% on an organic basis driven primarily by higher volume as we have now lapped the bulk of last year's price increases. Growth in LGM's high-value categories led by specialty labels continued to outpace the growth of the base business.
In breaking down LGM's organic growth in the quarter by region, North America was roughly flat, while Western Europe was up low-single digits. Emerging markets also grew at a low-single-digit rate, with China up low-single digits and South Asia up mid-single digits.
Adjusted operating margin for the segment was strong at 13.5%, up 120 basis points compared to the prior year, reflecting the benefit of productivity initiatives, including restructuring and material reengineering, partially offset by higher employee-related costs. A net effect of changes in price, and raw material freight input costs was neutral for the quarter. 
Shifting now to Retail Branding and Information Solutions. RBIS delivered solid top line growth, up 4.1% on an organic basis, driven by faster growth in high-value categories with RFID sales up roughly 20%, and external embellishments growing even faster.
Our base business, adjusted for the migration of products to higher-value RFID solutions, was down low single digits. 
Adjusted operating margin for the segment increased 10 basis points to 11.5% as productivity gains were largely offset by long-term growth-related investments, primarily related to RFID. 
Turning to the Industrial and Healthcare Materials segment. Sales were up 3.7% on an organic basis, reflecting both volume growth and higher prices. Sales for industrial categories were up low- to mid-single digits, driven by solid growth in auto-related categories. And healthcare categories grew even faster a high-single digits, with medical up in the high-teens.
And we made excellent progress on the margin front in IHM. Adjusted operating margin increased by 180 basis points to 11% as the benefits from higher volume and productivity more than offset higher employee-related costs. The normal seasonality does call for sequential easing in margin for the fourth quarter, I'm confident we'll achieve the 10% we targeted for IHM for the full here.
Focusing now on our outlook for 2019. We have lowered the high end of our guidance range for adjusted earnings per share, reflecting incremental currency translation headwinds, largely offset by stronger operational results in a modestly lower tax rate compared to our previous expectations. 
We have reduced our outlook for full year organic sales growth to our range of 2.0% to 2.3%, which implies 2% to 3% growth for the fourth quarter. 
As you know, in our short-cycle businesses, visibility to demand is very limited, and we're seeing increased variability in order patents from month-to-month. So the low end of our organic growth outlook assumes a continuation of the 2% we've seen year-to-date, including the first few weeks of October. On the high-end reflects the fact that comparison easier for us over the balance of the quarter.
We've outlined some of the other key confident and factored store guidance on Slide 9 of our supplemental presentation materials. In particular, we're just focusing on the material changes from our assumptions in July. At recent exchange rates, currency translation represents a roughly 3.5 point headwind to reported sales growth for the year, with the pretax operating income hit of $37 million and incremental of $9 million headwind relative to the $28 million we were anticipating in July.
Partially offsetting this, we now estimate that incremental pretax savings from restructuring net of transition costs, will contribute approximately $50 million, as the teams have been executing very well against our plans and we look to deliver at the high end of our previous expectations. We realized about $35 million of the savings in the first 3 quarters of the year. And the tax rate should come in slightly lower than our previous outlook, which I assumed 25% at the midpoint of our guidance range.
In summary, we delivered another solid quarter in a more challenging environment, and we remain on track to deliver on our long-term objectives to achieve GDP+ growth and top quartile returns on capital, which together drives sustained growth in EVA.
And now we'll open up the call for your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019

Which regions did you to capture share within from a geographic standpoint? What's your stance from customer as it relates to the outlook for 4Q in 2020? headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: So a lot in there, Ghansham. So specifically within the quarter. So basically, if you look within July, growth started out relatively soft, softened further in August and then came back in September. We're now seeing a bit of moderation as Greg talked abo
componenttext:
So a lot in there, Ghansham. So specifically within the quarter. So basically, if you look within July, growth started out relatively soft, softened further in August and then came back in September. We're now seeing a bit of moderation as Greg talked about early October, again. So a little bit more of choppiness that we've talked through. 
In North America, so just from a market perspective, in the markets, we've seen pretty consistent low-single-digit growth between last year and this year. Our growth, of course, was lower than that in the first half of the year because of the share losses, which we since believe we are on the solid path to recapturing. And in Europe, we saw low to mid-single-digit growth last year, as you know, in the first half really no growth pretty flattened environment and we are now seeing a little bit of a pickup low single digit growth in Q3 mostly and southern Europe, not not or Central Europe overall. And then in, I think, China, we saw low mid-digit last year growth, and we saw flattened first half of this year and started to see some positive growth here in Q3, mid-single digits. And South Asia as we called out, that's where we saw a shift, and it's really ASEAN. So India continues to have strong growth, high-single digits. And ASEAN, specifically Malaysia and Thailand, where we're seeing some softness, which we attribute broadly to just softer market conditions and the link between the China and U.S. trade matters.  So as far as [indiscernible] basically the sentiment reflects those market trends overall. So generally, the customer sentiment label recently was well attended by customers, particularly from Europe once in southern Europe and Eastern Europe a little bit more confident about near-term outlook than the ones from northern and Central Europe, specifically. Overall, a lot of excitement to about the innovations and a lot of interest in coming from customers what we can bring to the table helping together to grow the market.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019

componenttext: Okay. And then just my second question sticking with LGM, it looks like pricing starting to kind of flatten out year-over-year. That's been pretty consistent with what you said last quarter as well. But just kind of looking at the next few quarters, how would you have us model price mix? Do you expect a negative sign from that? Or do you think that, that will be a essentially flat just like it was in 3Q?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ghansham. This is Greg. Overall, we've seen pretty neutral net pricing inflation here in the third quarter versus prior and also relatively neutral sequentially. So we've seen a little sequential deflation, largely coming from some easing in paper he
componenttext: Yes, Ghansham. This is Greg. Overall, we've seen pretty neutral net pricing inflation here in the third quarter versus prior and also relatively neutral sequentially. So we've seen a little sequential deflation, largely coming from some easing in paper here in the third quarter. At the same time, we've got some pockets of price down, as we've seen some sequential deflation over the last couple of quarters. But overall, we're looking at kind of price inflation relatively neutral year-over-year in Q3 as well as sequentially essentially a little more a sequential modest deflation we think in Q4, but not a material impact overall.

Just hoping you could clarify what you attribute that to? headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So quite simply, Adam, the volatility we called it out a little bit more eased term choppiness and demand last quarter, we're continuing to see it. What do we attribute it to it's basically just some of the uncertainty that's going on in the environm
componenttext:
Yes. So quite simply, Adam, the volatility we called it out a little bit more eased term choppiness and demand last quarter, we're continuing to see it. What do we attribute it to it's basically just some of the uncertainty that's going on in the environment. If you look at political uncertainty around Brexit impacting Europe, if you look at what's going on in Hong Kong and then the trade matters tariffs on again, off again, on again. 
So those are what we attribute, in general, the more lumpiness not uncommon in LGM, in particular, to have a few weeks of just growth above normal or below normal, but we're just seeing more consistent into somewhat larger degree. And we're talking about still within a relatively tight band. It's not a dramatic swings, but we are seeing more choppiness and then we have traditionally seen in LGM as well as in RBIS. As far as the other part of your question about Greg explained to Q4?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019

componenttext: Yes. So Adam, this is Greg. In Q4 of last year, volumes month was in October and then volumes softened quite a bit November and December, so we did see a little bit easier comps in the back part of this quarter. Whereas, we started Q3 or started -- sorry, we started Q4, a little bit lower end of our range for the quarter.

componenttext: Yes. So I guess as we move through the year first half of the year we've seen some benefits in chemicals as we're moving across the quarters. And then paper started to be a benefit for us in Q4 -- or sorry in Q3. Overall though, still I think kind of low-single-digit type of deflation sequentially, very little in total with a little bit heavier in paper. So till not a huge impact, but low-single-digit deflation as we came into Q3 from -- largely from paper.

Would it be possible to give a bit more color in terms of what some of those incremental costs might have been in the third quarter or any other sources of deceleration in incremental margin within RBIS to the extent that you can comment?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, George, this is Greg. Just as you said the variable flow-through we got from the top line growth was largely in line with what we would have expected from that. At the same time, as you mentioned, as Mitch mentioned earlier, we have been continuing t
componenttext: Yes, George, this is Greg. Just as you said the variable flow-through we got from the top line growth was largely in line with what we would have expected from that. At the same time, as you mentioned, as Mitch mentioned earlier, we have been continuing to invest particularly in RFID. And we had investments in the quarter of a few million dollars versus where we were a year ago. So that's offsetting some of the variable flow-through, otherwise generally in line what quarter would have expected at that level.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019

George, and I think overall the margins you see for all of our business and particularly RBIS, the expansions we've been able to achieve are I think even more impressive when you consider how much we've invested, particularly in Intelligent Labels over the past couple years. So between last year and this year, we would have added more than $20 million of organic OpEX to this business really in the business development areas, and so forth that we talked through. And it's just reinforces our strategy is trying to invest more to accelerate growth in high-value categories a relentless focus on productivity to both find those investments as well as expand margins.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks. This is Greg. So overall, I think we -- as you said, we feel good about our performance against generally weaker industrial backdrop. There's a few areas where in addition to the fact that last year certainly from a comp perspective was reall
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks. This is Greg. So overall, I think we -- as you said, we feel good about our performance against generally weaker industrial backdrop. There's a few areas where in addition to the fact that last year certainly from a comp perspective was really starting to see the China market slow. So that was a year-over-year benefit. But in addition to that, our medical business, as you first talked about over the last fourth straight quarter, I guess, we've had growth in the high-teens in our medical business. So that business continues to perform very well, and it's certainly been taken some share in some target applications. 
We'll start to some of that high-teens growth here as we go into the fourth quarter, but feel very good about how that business has performed over the last year. 
And at the same time, on industrial for us, this is really an application-by-application base business. And here, we also feel like we want some share in some targeted applications in areas, such as building construction tapes in North America as an example area we continue to grow very well in. So it's a little bit easier comps in automotive, but still automotive market as a whole this year or in Q3 was still down auto production globally. And we did grow in that kind of low- to mid-single-digit range. So good about the performance here, as you said, against generally weaker industrial.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then on the LGM side, in terms you guys feeling that you got back most of your lost share, if the market remains kind of tepid here, do you see any risk of more share shifts back and forth? Maybe some context prior cycles with sl
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then on the LGM side, in terms you guys feeling that you got back most of your lost share, if the market remains kind of tepid here, do you see any risk of more share shifts back and forth? Maybe some context prior cycles with slower general growth, is there a lot of kind of back and forth of price pushes to try to gain volumes back now that you've kind of got your share again?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Generally, when we see the share moving around it's usually in periods of change. So rapid inflationary environments or deflationary environments is when we've tend to seen it, particularly at the beginning or ends of those cycles. So if we were to g
componenttext: Yes. Generally, when we see the share moving around it's usually in periods of change. So rapid inflationary environments or deflationary environments is when we've tend to seen it, particularly at the beginning or ends of those cycles. So if we were to go into slower growth, if that's your question, but stable environment, we haven't experienced that for a sustained period of time in our industry. Our industry is more resilient than that, but if we were to, I have nothing in our industry to tell us that, that would cause more variation in share positions.

componenttext:
Yes. So just based on kind of cost reduction, we would expect carryover from a restructuring perspective into 2020 of somewhere in the $20 million to $25 million range. A lot of that driven by the Europe restructuring that we've talked about quite a bit, but that savings at least started to kick in at the end of Q2 beginning of Q3 of this here. 
So I think we have that as a tailwind going into next year. At the same time, we have some headwinds, such as currency translation, which is a headwind for us in the back half of this here. It'll be a headwind than in the first half of next year for status rates and a few other items, which I think is well there. But overall, carryover restructuring about $20 million to $25 million.

So that's really been the biggest area of automotive growth here in Q3.

componenttext: In out of idea, it sounds like nonapparel opportunities are going better than you initially expected, and I think in the past you've identified through beauty aviation and logistics kind of 4 markets that were real opportunities outside of apparel. I'm just wondering if you can provide any color on those for markets maybe broadly and if there's anyone, in particular, where you're seeing customer wins or what customer our option has been kind of faster than you expected or anything that surprised you there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Anthony. Yes, so overall, the speed at which we've been able to build the pipeline has been rapid, and I don't think we gave projections about what we expected, but we are hitting our ambitions on that. And as I mentioned most of the growth in the a
componenttext:
Sure, Anthony. Yes, so overall, the speed at which we've been able to build the pipeline has been rapid, and I don't think we gave projections about what we expected, but we are hitting our ambitions on that. And as I mentioned most of the growth in the actual pipeline is from categories outside of apparel. Specifically, the biggest growth driver of that is really been within the food category. So foods, we have quite a few programs in the pipeline that we're working. As far as the actual growth, the growth levels is signed percentage respect very small base. So our focus here is leverage the strength that we have within the apparel segment, both from a business development as well as innovation and manufacturing capabilities and identify at that end markets where there are similarities apparel that we think are right for adoption to begin to build that. 
We're having some wins along the way, but a lot of this, the revenue right now outside of apparel a lot of them are at the pilot stage, and so for the pilot revenue, and there's a couple moving to full adoptions, but it's relatively small, less than 10 programs. So a vast majority of the pipeline is still early stage, and for us, it's really the growth opportunity particularly in the 2021, '22, '22 beyond is what we're really focused on as far as when it starts to become much more meaningful numbers.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So overall, we just saw tentativeness. We talked about the base apparel business slowing a little bit already, the rate of growth slowing in Q2 already and it further moderated here in Q3. We do see people trying to buy ahead of time because that w
componenttext:
Yes. So overall, we just saw tentativeness. We talked about the base apparel business slowing a little bit already, the rate of growth slowing in Q2 already and it further moderated here in Q3. 
We do see people trying to buy ahead of time because that was tentativeness people in general where just slow to move in overall. When we look at what's going on our growth trends when we talk to other players in the segment suppliers provide threats, and so forth, what they're saying is similar to what we are seeing. When you talk about actual retail and brand level, you have some retailers, some brands that are doing phenomenally well and others that are struggling. So that's a bit of a mixed bag, if you will, as far as what's going on in and retail environment. So we didn't really seen that any bills or anything. If you look at that material trends, inventory has dropped dramatically in '18, build up a little bit at the end of last year beginning of this year already to started depleting again. And these are levels that are near all-time lows right now as far as inventory levels, which I think just shows retailers and brands focused on the need for foster supply chains and lower inventory levels in this more uncertain environment we just further reinforces that option of our RFID.

componenttext: Yes, Rosemarie. So we set a target of 12.5% to 13.5%. As you said, we are in the upper end of that targeted range when we set those targets. We had -- last 2 times, we set long-term targets, we continually raise them, and we said that we were focused on, and we saw the opportunity for more, and so we expanded them at that time. At this level, this business is the returns are the multiple of cost of capital. So for us, we're not looking to adjust targets or anything for any of our businesses right now. Somewhere within them, once belows it, making a good trajectory to get within and another being RBIS is above it. We're not going to adjust our targets comment on that at this time when we set our next set of long-term targets we'll adjust accordingly. But I think, the key message here is, we got a good growth, high-return business here in LGM that we see, feel great about our position and prospects for.

componenttext: Well, we think the business can grow at a pretty high clip, well above the average and it's been about 10%, above 20% this year. Business is less than 10% of overall RBIS. componenttext: Yes. So primarily, it's the tactics are if some business moves away for a bit is be patient and diligent and we know that we've got superior service and quality. And just continue to dialogue with those customers and eventually the share rebalances. The other thing that happens is we went from the last price increase when we where at the end of inflationary cycle to in some areas, some communities seeing some deflation so where we saw that we had a relative a price premium that was move maybe outside of the targeted bank that we think particular product or solution warrants. We will then just ate at that level. So there's some pricing that to be focused on being competitive. And that's not broad-based. That's maybe targeted areas. But overall focus here is be patient and diligent. We have built our tremendous capabilities as far as service and quality and be confident that might play out for a few quarters.

Water bottles and straws, and so forth pressure sensitive lower bills very few of those products. And that's where you're seeing a lot of migration over in general my view is that, that is an appropriate focus on sustainability of packaging in general. It's a key focus of the industry. It's a key focus of our spirit we've been we are out in front many companies especially packagers making sustainability approximately at say first wave of that was more on improving sustainability of our own business dramatically reduced greenhouse gases by 30% over the last number of years buying more sustainable sustainably sourced raw materials, such as more than 90% of the paper that we procure is sustainably certified, such as ship Council. So that is in focus and our more recently we've been shifting more on picking sure that our products make recyclability much more easy and efficient. So we think this is an overall longer term trend for us. We see this is something more of a longer-term drive. We sit important where the market leader increasing our levels investment innovation in this space because we intend to lead there.

Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Avery Dennison's earnings conference call for the third quarter ended September 28, 2019. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 12:00 p.m. Pacific Time today through midnight Pacific Time, October 26. To access the replay, please dial (800) 633-8284 or +1 (402) 977-9140 for international callers. The conference ID number is 21896770.
I would now like to turn the call over to Cindy Guenther, Avery Dennison's Vice President of Investor Relations and Finance. Please go ahead, madam.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ash. Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited third quarter results. Please note that throughout today's discussion, we'll be making references to non-GAAP financial measures. The non-GAAP measures that we use are defined, qualified and r
componenttext:
Thank you, Ash. Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited third quarter results. Please note that throughout today's discussion, we'll be making references to non-GAAP financial measures. The non-GAAP measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP on Pages A-4 to A-8 attached to the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release and the appendix of our supplemental presentation materials.
We remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These forward-looking statements are made subject to the safe harbor statement included in today's earnings release.
On the call today are Mitch Butier, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Lovins, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
I'll now turn the call over to Mitch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good day, everyone. We delivered solid profit growth in the third quarter, despite softer-than-usual market demand with EPS once again up double digits over prior year on a constant currency basis. Our focus in this slower growth enviro
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good day, everyone. We delivered solid profit growth in the third quarter, despite softer-than-usual market demand with EPS once again up double digits over prior year on a constant currency basis. Our focus in this slower growth environment had been to protect even expand our margins in the base business while driving faster-than-average growth in high-value categories, like RFID.
We're executing well on both fronts. We appear to have recaptured most of the share we recently lost in LGM. Our Intelligent Labels platform continued to drive over 20% growth from RFID-enabled solutions, and IHM's commercial execution continues to improve. At the same time, our relentless focus on productivity was, again, a key driver of the margin expansion for the company this quarter. In sum, we are making good progress against our key strategic priorities and are on track to deliver our long-term financial targets.
Label and Graphic Materials posted strong profitability on roughly a point of organic growth for the quarter, driven primarily by volume. High-value categories, again, grew faster than the base. As I mentioned, though all of the market data isn't in yet for the third quarter, we have good reason to believe that by the end of the quarter, we had recaptured the bulk of the share we ceded at the tail end of the inflationary cycle.
In terms of global market trends, it appears that the soft market conditions that we saw in the first half of the year largely continued into the third quarter, with a modest improvement in Europe offset by a moderation of demand in South Asia.
Retail Branding and Information Solutions delivered solid organic growth, driven by ongoing strength in RFID and external embellishments, which more than offset declines in the base apparel business. As we mentioned in July, we saw trade-related uncertainty impacting orders in the second quarter. This uncertainty was reinforced when additional tariffs were announced in August. Now while trade-related issues are causing near-term uncertainty, we are well positioned in the base business, given our global footprint and differentiated product and service capabilities.
As for RFID, the growth trajectory continues to be resilient, with continued strength in apparel and even faster growth from other promising verticals though obviously off of a small base. Our total pipeline of customer engagements continue to expand, up more than 40% from just the beginning of this year, driven primarily by categories outside of apparel.
As the leader in ultrahigh frequency RFID, we are positioned extremely well to capture these opportunities with industry-leading innovation and manufacturing capabilities and the best most experienced team in the space. We continue to increase our level of investment in business development and other resources to drive this growth as we build out our Intelligent Labels platform to enable a future where every item can have a digital twin and digital life.
In Industrial and Healthcare Materials, sales growth was relatively strong on an organic basis due in part to lapping the slowdown in China's automotive market last year. That said, given the high proportion of this segment's portfolio that is focused on industrial and markets, I'm pleased with the solid top line performance the team delivered. And importantly, we made excellent progress in the quarter towards achieving our operating margin target for the business.
In short, another solid quarter overall in the midst of a challenging environment. Our strategies to deliver outsized growth in high-value categories are working, and our relentless focus on productivity continues to enable us to increase our pace of investment in these categories, increase our competitiveness overall and grow profitably in our base businesses while importantly, continuing to protect and expand operating margin.
While we lowered the high end of our near-term outlook for top line growth due to recent market trends and currency shift caused us to reduce the high end of our EPS guidance for the year, we are confident in our ability to achieve our long-term objectives, including GDP+ growth and top quartile returns. We will continue to seek opportunities to leverage our position of strength commercially, operationally and financially and as you've heard me say before, be prepared to lean forward even as others may pull back.
Now I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and hello, everybody. As Mitch said, we delivered another solid quarter, with adjusted earnings per share of $1.66, up 14% despite the currency headwind. We grew sales by 2.1% on an organic basis, and currency translation reduced reported sales gr
componenttext:
Thanks, and hello, everybody. As Mitch said, we delivered another solid quarter, with adjusted earnings per share of $1.66, up 14% despite the currency headwind. We grew sales by 2.1% on an organic basis, and currency translation reduced reported sales growth by 2 points in the quarter. And our adjusted operating margin increased by a full point to 11.7%. 
We realized $18 million of restructuring savings net of transition costs in the quarter due in part to LGM's restructuring in the Europe that was largely completed as of the end of Q2. And our cash generation has been strong. We've delivered $327 million of free cash flow year-to-date, up $67 million compared to the same period last year.
As we've discussed, we've increased our pace of fixed capital in IT-related spending for a few years to support our long-term organic growth and margin expansion plans, with capital spending expected to be up by about $20 million this year. And we continue to return cash to shareholders. In the first 3 quarters of the year, we repurchased roughly 2 million shares at an aggregate cost of $204 million and paid $141 million in dividends for a total of $346 million of cash returned to shareholders.
Importantly, our balance sheet remained strong with net debt-to-adjusted-EBITDA ticking down slightly in the quarter. Our current leverage position gives us ample capacity to continue executing our disciplined capital allocation strategy, including investing in organic growth and acquisitions while continuing to return cash to shareholders. We are well positioned to take advantage of any dislocations in the market, should they occur over the next few years.
Turning to the segment results for the quarter. Label and Graphic Materials sales increased by 1.2% on an organic basis, driven primarily by higher volume as we've now lapped the bulk of last year's price increases. Growth in LGM's high-value categories led by specialty labels continued to outpace the growth of the base business.
And breaking down LGM's organic growth in the quarter by region, North America was roughly flat, while Western Europe was up low single digits. Emerging markets also grew at a low single-digit rate, with China up low single digits and South Asia up mid-single digits.
Adjusted operating margin for the segment was strong at 13.5%, up 120 basis points compared to the prior year, reflecting the benefit of productivity initiatives, including restructuring and material reengineering, partially offset by higher employee-related costs. The net effect of changes in price and raw material and freight input cost was neutral for the quarter.
Shifting now to Retail Branding and Information Solutions. RBIS delivered solid top line growth, up 4.1% on an organic basis, driven by faster growth in high-value categories with RFID sales up roughly 20% and external embellishments growing even faster. Our base business, adjusted for the migration of products to higher-value RFID solutions, was down low single digits. Adjusted operating margin for the segment increased 10 basis points to 11.5% as productivity gains were largely offset by long-term growth-related investments, primarily related to RFID.
Turning to the Industrial and Healthcare Materials segment. Sales were up 3.7% on an organic basis, reflecting both volume growth and higher prices. Sales for industrial categories were up low to mid-single digits, driven by solid growth in auto-related categories. And health care categories grew even faster, up high single digits, with medical up in the high teens. And we made excellent progress on the margin front in IHM. Adjusted operating margin increased by 180 basis points to 11% as the benefits from higher volume and productivity more than offset higher employee-related costs. The normal seasonality does call for sequential easing in margin for the fourth quarter, I'm confident we'll achieve the 10% we targeted for IHM for the full year.
Focusing now on our outlook for 2019. We have lowered the high end of our guidance range for adjusted earnings per share, reflecting incremental currency translation headwinds, largely offset by stronger operational results in a modestly lower tax rate compared to our previous expectations. We have reduced our outlook for full year organic sales growth to a range of 2.0% to 2.3%, which implies 2% to 3% growth for the fourth quarter.
As you know, in our short-cycle businesses, visibility to demand is very limited, and we're seeing increased variability in order patterns from month-to-month. So the low end of our organic growth outlook assumes a continuation of the 2% we've seen year-to-date, including the first few weeks of October while the high-end reflects the fact that comparisons do get easier for us over the balance of the quarter.
We've outlined some of the other key contributing factors to our guidance on Slide 9 of our supplemental presentation materials. In particular, we're just focusing on the material changes from our assumptions in July. At recent exchange rates, currency translation represents a roughly 3.5 point headwind to reported sales growth for the year, with the pretax operating income hit of $37 million and incremental of $9 million headwind relative to the $28 million we were anticipating in July.
Partially offsetting this, we now estimate that incremental pretax savings from restructuring, net of transition costs, will contribute approximately $50 million, as the teams have been executing very well against our plans and we look to deliver at the high end of our previous expectations. We realized about $35 million of these savings in the first 3 quarters of the year. And the tax rate should come in slightly lower than our previous outlook, which I had assumed 25% at the midpoint of our guidance range.
In summary, we delivered another solid quarter in a more challenging environment, and we remain on track to deliver on our long-term objectives to achieve GDP+ growth and top quartile returns on capital, which together drives sustained growth in EVA.
And now we'll open up the call for your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: So a lot in there, Ghansham, specifically within the quarter. So basically, if you look within July, growth started out relatively soft. It softened further in August and then came back in September. We're now seeing a bit of a moderation as Greg talked a
componenttext:
So a lot in there, Ghansham, specifically within the quarter. So basically, if you look within July, growth started out relatively soft. It softened further in August and then came back in September. We're now seeing a bit of a moderation as Greg talked about early October again. So a little bit more of the choppiness that we've talked through.
In North America, so just from a market perspective, in the markets, we've seen pretty consistent low single-digit growth between last year and this year. Our growth, of course, was lower than that in the first half of the year because of the share losses, which we since believe we're on the solid path to recapturing.
And in Europe, we saw low to mid-single-digit growth last year, as you know, and the first half really no growth, pretty flat environment, and we're now seeing a little bit of a pickup low single-digit growth in Q3 mostly in Southern Europe, not north or Central Europe overall. And then in, I think, China, we saw low mid-digit last year growth, and we saw flattened first half of this year and started to see some positive growth here in Q3, mid-single digits. And South Asia, as we called out, that's where we saw a shift, and it's really ASEAN. So India continues to have strong growth, high single digits. And ASEAN, specifically Malaysia and Thailand, where we're seeing some softness, which we attribute broadly to just softer market conditions and the link between the China and U.S. trade matters.
So as far as sentiment from the customer, basically the sentiment reflects those market trends overall. So generally, the customer sentiment, we just had Labelexpo recently. It was well attended by customers, particularly from Europe, the ones in Southern Europe and Eastern Europe sounded a little bit more confident about the near-term outlook than the ones from northern and Central Europe, specifically. Overall, a lot of excitement though about the innovations and a lot of interest coming from customers of what we can bring to the table and help together to grow the market.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my second question sticking with LGM, it looks like price is starting to kind of flatten out year-over-year. That's been pretty consistent with what you said last quarter as well. But just kind of looking out the next few quarters, how
componenttext: Okay. And then just my second question sticking with LGM, it looks like price is starting to kind of flatten out year-over-year. That's been pretty consistent with what you said last quarter as well. But just kind of looking out the next few quarters, how would you have us model price mix? Should we expect a negative sign from that? Or do you think that, that will be essentially flat, just like it was in 3Q?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ghansham, this is Greg. So overall, we've seen pretty neutral net pricing inflation here in the third quarter versus prior year and also relatively neutral sequentially. So we've seen a little bit of sequential deflation, largely coming from some eas
componenttext: Yes. Ghansham, this is Greg. So overall, we've seen pretty neutral net pricing inflation here in the third quarter versus prior year and also relatively neutral sequentially. So we've seen a little bit of sequential deflation, largely coming from some easing in paper here in the third quarter. At the same time, we've got some pockets of price down, as we've seen some sequential deflation over the last couple of quarters. But overall, we're looking at kind of price inflation relatively neutral year-over-year in Q3 as well as sequentially, essentially a little more a sequential modest deflation we think in Q4, but not a material impact overall.

componenttext: Mitch or Greg, just one question on Greg's comments toward the end of the prepared remarks. You talked about seeing increased variability in your order patterns from month-to-month. Just hoping you could clarify what you attribute that to. And then you talked about first couple weeks in October being up low to similar to what you had in 3Q, but I think for the quarter, you're thinking anywhere from 2% to 3%, I guess, because the comps get easier as the quarter goes along. So I'm just hoping to understand these 2 issues a bit better.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So quite simply, Adam, the volatility we called it out a little bit more -- we used the term choppiness in demand last quarter. We're continuing to see it. What do we attribute it to, it's basically just some of the uncertainty that's going on in the
componenttext:
Yes. So quite simply, Adam, the volatility we called it out a little bit more -- we used the term choppiness in demand last quarter. We're continuing to see it. What do we attribute it to, it's basically just some of the uncertainty that's going on in the environment. If you look at political uncertainty around Brexit impacting Europe, if you look at what's going on in Hong Kong and then the trade matters, tariffs on again, off again, on again. So those are what we attribute, in general, the more lumpiness.
Not uncommon in LGM, in particular, to have a few weeks of just growth above normal or below normal, but we're just being seeing it more consistent into somewhat larger degree. And we're talking about still within a relatively tight band. It's not dramatic swings, but we are seeing more choppiness than we've traditionally seen in LGM as well as in RBIS. As far as the other part of your question about the -- I think Greg explain Q4.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Adam, this is Greg. In Q4 of last year, our strongest volume month was in October and then volumes softened quite a bit November and December, so we did see a little bit easier comps in the back part of this quarter, whereas we started Q3 or start
componenttext: Yes. So Adam, this is Greg. In Q4 of last year, our strongest volume month was in October and then volumes softened quite a bit November and December, so we did see a little bit easier comps in the back part of this quarter, whereas we started Q3 or started -- sorry, we started Q4 a little bit the lower end of our range for the quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019

componenttext: And just one on the raw materials. I think Ghansham asked about raw materials or price cost. Specifically, you said it was flat, and you expect similar trends thereafter. Can you talk about what exactly you saw with your paper cost and your chemical cost in 3Q? Obviously, it's been quite a bit of global paper market weakness, and we're just trying to get a sense of precisely how much your paper cost fell either sequentially or year-over-year and what you're seeing in terms of paper prices going down?

componenttextpreview: Yes. So I guess as we move through the year, in the first half of the year we'd seen some benefits in chemicals as we're moving across the quarters. And then paper started to be a benefit for us in Q4 -- or sorry, in Q3. Overall though, still I think kind
componenttext: Yes. So I guess as we move through the year, in the first half of the year we'd seen some benefits in chemicals as we're moving across the quarters. And then paper started to be a benefit for us in Q4 -- or sorry, in Q3. Overall though, still I think kind of low single-digit type of deflation sequentially, very little in total with a little bit heavier in paper. So still not a huge impact, but low single-digit deflation as we came into Q3 from -- largely from paper.

Is that totally surprising given the cadence of restructuring and every quarter can't be phenomenal? And you also called out the spending on growth within RBIS. Would it be possible to give a bit more color in terms of what some of those incremental costs might have been in the third quarter or any other sources of deceleration in incremental margin within RBIS to the extent that you can comment?

componenttextpreview: Yes, George, this is Greg. So just as you said, the variable flow-through we got from the top line growth was largely in line with what we would have expected from that. At the same time, as you mentioned, as Mitch mentioned earlier, we have been continui
componenttext: Yes, George, this is Greg. So just as you said, the variable flow-through we got from the top line growth was largely in line with what we would have expected from that. At the same time, as you mentioned, as Mitch mentioned earlier, we have been continuing to invest particularly in RFID. And we had investments in the quarter of a few million dollars versus where we were a year ago. So that offsetting some of the variable flow-through, otherwise generally in line with what we would have expected at that level.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay, George, and I think just overall just the margins you see for all of our businesses and particularly RBIS, the expansions we've been able to achieve are I think even more impressive when you consider how much we've invested, particularly in Intellig
componenttext: Okay, George, and I think just overall just the margins you see for all of our businesses and particularly RBIS, the expansions we've been able to achieve are I think even more impressive when you consider how much we've invested, particularly in Intelligent Labels over the past couple of years. So between last year and this year, we will have added more than $20 million of organic OpEX to this business really in the business development areas and so forth that we talked through. And this just reinforces that our strategy is trying to invest more to accelerate growth in high-value categories and a relentless focus on productivity to both fund those investments as well as expand margins.

componenttext: So George, I'm not going to get into specifics of that. Just overall, I think you've captured it. This is a key strategy of ours. It's one of the key 4 strategic pillars, the relentless focus on productivity, and we see restructuring as one of a number of levers to pull. Our constant focus is on material reengineering, Lean Sigma are key tenets of our strategy and restructuring we think of as innovation of our fixed cost structure. So we will communicate that as we normally do with annual guidance on what to expect for the given year and as we roll out these programs and so forth. So that's -- we're not going to comment on any specifics now, but I think the overall long-term strategy, you should expect that to continue to unfold.
