headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks. This is Greg. So overall, I think we -- as you said, we feel good about our performance against a generally kind of weaker industrial backdrop. There's a few areas where, in addition to the fact that last year, certainly from a comp perspecti
componenttext:
Yes, thanks. This is Greg. So overall, I think we -- as you said, we feel good about our performance against a generally kind of weaker industrial backdrop. There's a few areas where, in addition to the fact that last year, certainly from a comp perspective, was when we really started to see the China auto market slow. So that was a year-over-year benefit. But in addition to that, our medical business, as you've heard us talk about over the last, well, this is our fourth straight quarter, I guess, where we've had growth in the high teens in our medical business. So that business continues to perform very well and has certainly been taking some share in some target applications. We'll start to lap some of that high-teens growth here as we go into the fourth quarter, but feel very good about how that business has performed over the last year.
And at the same time, on industrial, for us, this is really an application-by-application based business. And here, we also feel like we won some share in some target applications in areas such as building construction [ tapes ] in North America as an example is an area we continue to grow very well in. So it's a little bit the easier comps in automotive, but still automotive market as a whole this year or in Q3 was still down, auto production globally. And we did grow in kind of low to mid-single-digit range. So I feel good about the performance here, as you said, against generally weaker industrial.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then on the LGM side, in terms you guys feeling that you got back most of your lost share, if the market remains kind of tepid here, do you see any risk of more share shifts back and forth? Maybe some context in prior cycles with
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then on the LGM side, in terms you guys feeling that you got back most of your lost share, if the market remains kind of tepid here, do you see any risk of more share shifts back and forth? Maybe some context in prior cycles with slower general growth, is there a lot of kind of back and forth or price pushes to try to gain volumes back now that you've kind of got your share again?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Generally, when we see the share moving around, it's usually in periods of change. So rapid inflationary environments or deflationary environments is when we tend to have seen it, particularly at the beginning or ends of those cycles. So if we were t
componenttext: Yes. Generally, when we see the share moving around, it's usually in periods of change. So rapid inflationary environments or deflationary environments is when we tend to have seen it, particularly at the beginning or ends of those cycles. So if we were to go into slower growth, if that's your question, but stable environment, we haven't experienced that for a sustained period of time in our industry. Our industry is more resilient than that. But if we were to, I have nothing in our history to tell us that, that would cause more variation in share positions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John McNulty with BMO.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John McNulty with BMO.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: With regard to the margin improvement that you've been seeing from the cost cuts, it sounds like you're going to end the year certainly higher than you started the year out. So I guess when you think about the year-end run rate for 2019 and how we should
componenttext: With regard to the margin improvement that you've been seeing from the cost cuts, it sounds like you're going to end the year certainly higher than you started the year out. So I guess when you think about the year-end run rate for 2019 and how we should think about kind of the improvement that you can see in 2020 without any incremental cuts, I guess how should we be thinking about what that incremental bridge is from '19 to '20, based on the cost cuts you've already put through?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just based on kind of cost reduction, we would expect carryover from a restructuring perspective into 2020 of somewhere in the $20 million to $25 million range. A lot of that driven by the Europe restructuring that we've talked about quite a bit,
componenttext: Yes. So just based on kind of cost reduction, we would expect carryover from a restructuring perspective into 2020 of somewhere in the $20 million to $25 million range. A lot of that driven by the Europe restructuring that we've talked about quite a bit, but that savings really started to kick in at the end of Q2, beginning of Q3 of this year. So I think we have that as a tailwind going into next year. At the same time, we have some headwinds, such as currency translation, which is a headwind for us here in the back half of this year. It'll be a headwind then in the first half of next year if we stay at these rates. And a few other items as headwinds, I think, as well there. But overall, carryover restructuring about $20 million to $25 million.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. Great. And then with regard to -- I think you had said autos were actually up in the quarter. And I guess we understand that there were some relatively easy comps. But admittedly, you may be the only company we look at that actually had positive a
componenttext: Got it. Great. And then with regard to -- I think you had said autos were actually up in the quarter. And I guess we understand that there were some relatively easy comps. But admittedly, you may be the only company we look at that actually had positive auto numbers. So I guess what's driving that? Is that new vehicles that you're on? Is it new applications that you're finding per vehicle? Like, I guess how should we think about what's really driving that growth when auto comps are clearly going down?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So a lot of our auto growth in the quarter actually did come in China, where we had some significant clients, as we talked about over the past year before this quarter. But that market, it really slowed. And we saw some -- while that market is still
componenttext: Yes. So a lot of our auto growth in the quarter actually did come in China, where we had some significant clients, as we talked about over the past year before this quarter. But that market, it really slowed. And we saw some -- while that market is still soft overall from an auto production perspective, we did some of our business start to pick up a little bit in the third quarter. So that's really been the biggest area of automotive growth here in Q3.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citigroup Global Markets Incorporated.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citigroup Global Markets Incorporated.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: In RFID, it sounds like non-apparel opportunities are going better than you initially expected, and I think in the past you've identified food, beauty, aviation and logistics as kind of 4 markets that were real opportunities outside of apparel. I'm just w
componenttext: In RFID, it sounds like non-apparel opportunities are going better than you initially expected, and I think in the past you've identified food, beauty, aviation and logistics as kind of 4 markets that were real opportunities outside of apparel. I'm just wondering if you can provide any color on those 4 markets, maybe broadly. And if there's anyone in particular where you're seeing customer wins or where customer adoption has been kind of faster than you've expected or anything that surprised you there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Anthony. Yes, so overall, the speed at which we've been able to build the pipeline has been rapid, and I don't think we gave projections about what we expected, but we are hitting our ambitions on that. And as I mentioned, most of the growth in the
componenttext:
Sure, Anthony. Yes, so overall, the speed at which we've been able to build the pipeline has been rapid, and I don't think we gave projections about what we expected, but we are hitting our ambitions on that. And as I mentioned, most of the growth in the actual pipeline is for categories outside of apparel. Specifically, the biggest growth driver of that has really been within the food category. So foods, we have quite a few programs in the pipeline that we're working.
As far as the actual growth, the growth levels, it's high in percentage terms but it's off of a very small base. So our focus here is leverage the strength that we have within the apparel segment, both from a business development as well innovation and manufacturing capabilities and identify other end markets where there are similarities to apparel that we think are right for adoption to begin to build that.
We're having some wins along the way, but a lot of this -- the revenue right now outside of apparel, a lot of them are at the pilot stage and so forth to pilot revenue. There's a couple moving to full adoptions, but it's relatively small, less than 10 programs. So a vast majority of the pipeline is still early stage. And for us, it's really the growth opportunity, particularly in the 2021, '22. '22 beyond is what we're really focused on as far as when it starts to become much more meaningful numbers.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just sticking with RBIS, maybe more broadly, you referenced uncertainty around tariffs. Did you see kind of a pull forward in RBIS demand and maybe the first half with Chinese customers trying to buy ahead of potential tarif
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just sticking with RBIS, maybe more broadly, you referenced uncertainty around tariffs. Did you see kind of a pull forward in RBIS demand and maybe the first half with Chinese customers trying to buy ahead of potential tariffs on apparel? Or are you seeing customers more kind of sitting on the sidelines? Can you say anything about sort of customer inventory levels currently and when they could resume kind of more normal buying patterns?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So overall, we just saw tentativeness. We talked about the base apparel business slowing a little bit already, the rate of growth slowing in Q2 already and it further moderated here in Q3. We didn't see people trying to buy ahead of time because it w
componenttext:
Yes. So overall, we just saw tentativeness. We talked about the base apparel business slowing a little bit already, the rate of growth slowing in Q2 already and it further moderated here in Q3. We didn't see people trying to buy ahead of time because it was just -- there was tentativeness and people in general were just slow to move overall. When we look at what's going on, our growth trends when we talk to other players in the segment suppliers, people who provide threads and so forth, what they're seeing is similar to what we are seeing.
Now, when you talk about actual at the retail and brand level, you have some retailers, some brands that are doing phenomenally well and others that are struggling. So there was a bit of a mixed bag, if you will, as far as what's going on in retail environment. So we didn't really see inventory builds or anything. If you look at the inventory trends, inventory has dropped dramatically in '18, built up a little bit at the end of last year, beginning of this year, but then have already started depleting again. And these are levels that are near all-time lows right now as far as inventory levels, which I think just shows retailers and brands focused on the need for faster supply chains and lower inventory levels in this more uncertain environment, which just further reinforces the adoption of RFID.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company Incorporated.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company Incorporated.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if -- on LGM, you have obviously reached your margin targets. It is a strong level you have. You are done with restructuring Europe. How much more do you think we can see this target improving? I mean not the target, but the margin itself.
componenttext: I was wondering if -- on LGM, you have obviously reached your margin targets. It is a strong level you have. You are done with restructuring Europe. How much more do you think we can see this target improving? I mean not the target, but the margin itself.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rosemarie. So we set a target of 12.5% to 13.5%. As you said, we are in the upper end of that targeted range. When we set those targets, we had -- last 2 times, we had set long-term targets. We continually raise them, and we said that we were focused
componenttext:
Yes, Rosemarie. So we set a target of 12.5% to 13.5%. As you said, we are in the upper end of that targeted range. When we set those targets, we had -- last 2 times, we had set long-term targets. We continually raise them, and we said that we were focused on and we saw the opportunity for more, and so we expanded them at that time. At this level, this business is -- the returns are to multiple of the cost of capital.
So for us, we're not looking to adjust targets or anything for any of our businesses right now. Some are within them. One is below it, making good trajectory to get it within and another being RBIS is above it. We're not going to adjust our targets or comment on that at this time. When we set our next set of long-term targets, we'll adjust accordingly. But I think the key message here is we got a good growth, high-return business here in LGM that we see -- feel great about our position and prospects for.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: All right. And then I was wondering if you could touch on M&A and the potential of seeing something between -- maybe not now and the end of the year, but up in the near future?
componenttext: All right. And then I was wondering if you could touch on M&A and the potential of seeing something between -- maybe not now and the end of the year, but up in the near future?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in M&A, timing is always tough to call. Pipeline's full, lot of engagements. I will say prices remain stickier for longer than we probably would have previously anticipated. So we're going to be disciplined as we go through this. Our focus here is
componenttext: Yes. So in M&A, timing is always tough to call. Pipeline's full, lot of engagements. I will say prices remain stickier for longer than we probably would have previously anticipated. So we're going to be disciplined as we go through this. Our focus here is disproportionally focusing on areas that will increase our exposure to high-value segments and calling something specifically within announcing in a 3-, 6-month period is just too tough to call. So not going to comment on that specifically.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Paretosh Misra with Berenberg Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Paretosh Misra with Berenberg Capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: So in your IHM segment, within the medical products, is there any specific product launch or application that is driving the strong growth?
componenttext: So in your IHM segment, within the medical products, is there any specific product launch or application that is driving the strong growth?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's pretty broad-based for us across our applications, and we continued to grow well in some of our core business. We've also been growing in some of our antimicrobial business, what we call CHG, that we've launched over the last year or so. So we'r
componenttext: Yes. It's pretty broad-based for us across our applications, and we continued to grow well in some of our core business. We've also been growing in some of our antimicrobial business, what we call CHG, that we've launched over the last year or so. So we're seeing a little bit of growth coming from new products from that perspective, but pretty broad-based across our portfolio over the last few quarters.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then a follow-up on the RBIS segment. I think you mentioned something on embellishments. So how big is that? And -- at what do you think that growth rate is sustainable?
componenttext: Got it. And then a follow-up on the RBIS segment. I think you mentioned something on embellishments. So how big is that? And -- at what do you think that growth rate is sustainable?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, we think this business can grow at a pretty high clip, well above the average, and it's been about 10%, above 20% this year. Business is less than 10% of overall RBIS, and so it's relatively small. We've been talking about this for a few years and s
componenttext: Well, we think this business can grow at a pretty high clip, well above the average, and it's been about 10%, above 20% this year. Business is less than 10% of overall RBIS, and so it's relatively small. We've been talking about this for a few years and started off from essentially nothing about 5 years ago and been growing it, and it's -- but it's still sub-10%. So we see good amount of opportunities to continue to expand it. This is taking our capabilities, both innovation and product capabilities as well as our manufacturing presence, to basically move from [ trim ] and being -- having external -- having embellishments inside the garment to outside the garment. And the key driver for growth right now for us is in the European soccer clubs.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Kapsch with Loop Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Kapsch with Loop Capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the dynamics around your comments about gaining back market share within LGM. So you said that -- in the past, you've talked about when these things happen, you tend to lean on superior service and quality more so than price as a means
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the dynamics around your comments about gaining back market share within LGM. So you said that -- in the past, you've talked about when these things happen, you tend to lean on superior service and quality more so than price as a means to get back share. Can you just characterize if that's sort of what the tactics have been in this instance, as you said, to gain back the share that you did or be in a position to gain back the share, at least? It sounds like you characterized it that way.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So primarily, the tactics are, if some business moves away for a bit, is be patient and diligent, and we know that we've got superior service and quality and just continue the dialogue with those customers and eventually the share rebalances. The oth
componenttext: Yes. So primarily, the tactics are, if some business moves away for a bit, is be patient and diligent, and we know that we've got superior service and quality and just continue the dialogue with those customers and eventually the share rebalances. The other thing that happens is we went from the last price increase when we were at the end of inflationary cycle to, in some areas, some commodities seeing some deflation. So where we saw that we had a relative price premium that was maybe outside of the targeted band that we think a particular product or solution warrants, we will then adjust at that level. So there's some pricing there to be focused on being competitive. And that's not broad-based. That's maybe targeted areas. But the overall focus here is be patient and diligent. We have built those tremendous capabilities as far as service and quality and be confident in that and let it play out for a few quarters.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: And if I could just follow-up on that, is -- would you characterize the regain market share consistent by region and then getting more granular on that? Is it enough to explain why this sales growth in southern Europe and then in the North America where y
componenttext: And if I could just follow-up on that, is -- would you characterize the regain market share consistent by region and then getting more granular on that? Is it enough to explain why this sales growth in southern Europe and then in the North America where you were flat, if you gain back shares, [ that should ] suggest that the overall market is -- was negative in the quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: So it's important our share gain comments are mostly sequential comments. And so the share gain was not relative so much to Q3 of last year. It's more from the first half of this year. So when we are talking about market growth, the comments that we made,
componenttext: So it's important our share gain comments are mostly sequential comments. And so the share gain was not relative so much to Q3 of last year. It's more from the first half of this year. So when we are talking about market growth, the comments that we made, those are year-over-year. So the share gain was not a driver of year-over-year growth as much as it was sequential.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: We have a follow-up question from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: We have a follow-up question from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just one housekeeping one and one on sustainability. On the housekeeping one, Greg or whomever, can you -- I know the Chinese yuan has strengthened quite a bit in recent weeks. So can you help me with what FX rates you're using for 4Q?
componenttext: Just one housekeeping one and one on sustainability. On the housekeeping one, Greg or whomever, can you -- I know the Chinese yuan has strengthened quite a bit in recent weeks. So can you help me with what FX rates you're using for 4Q?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our RMB -- sorry, our euro rate is just around under 1.10 in the quarter, so I think 1.09-point something in the quarter for the euro and the RMB is a little over 0.14 for the quarter.
componenttext: Yes. So our RMB -- sorry, our euro rate is just around under 1.10 in the quarter, so I think 1.09-point something in the quarter for the euro and the RMB is a little over 0.14 for the quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: 0.14, okay. And just on the -- Mitch, on sustainability, there's a lot of talk about potential shift out of PET bottles toward aluminum, just given CPG companies desire to rid themselves of plastic to the extent possible. Can you just give us your view of
componenttext: 0.14, okay. And just on the -- Mitch, on sustainability, there's a lot of talk about potential shift out of PET bottles toward aluminum, just given CPG companies desire to rid themselves of plastic to the extent possible. Can you just give us your view of this whole sustainability movement and talk about what if any impact you're seeing on our business? I would assume it's negligible, just given the types of labels that go on those bottles, but anything more, I would appreciate.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the largest primary focus right now is really around single-use plastic containers, and there's varying definitions for what that is. But if you think of water bottles and straws and so forth, pressure-sensitive labels are -- go on very few of tho
componenttext: Yes. So the largest primary focus right now is really around single-use plastic containers, and there's varying definitions for what that is. But if you think of water bottles and straws and so forth, pressure-sensitive labels are -- go on very few of those products. And that's where you're seeing a lot of the migration over. In general, my view is, is that there is an appropriate focus on sustainability of packaging in general. It's a key focus of the industry, it's a key focus of ours. We've been -- we're out in front of many companies, especially packagers are making sustainability a priority, and I'd say the first wave of that was more around improving sustainability of our own business, dramatically reduce greenhouse gases by 30% over the last number of years, buying more sustainably sourced raw materials, such as more than 90% of our paper that we procure is sustainably certified, such as Forest Stewardship Council. So that has been the focus, and now more recently we've been shifting more on making sure that our products make recyclability much more easy and efficient. So we think this is an overall longer-term trend for us. We see it as something more of a longer-term drive. We think it's important. We're the market leader. We're increasing our levels of investment in innovation in this space because we intend to lead here.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on topics that come up periodically on your calls that -- regarding displacement types of technologies relative to your core products. So we're at PACK EXPO recently, and we saw -- it seemed to us anyway a lot more commentary by
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on topics that come up periodically on your calls that -- regarding displacement types of technologies relative to your core products. So we're at PACK EXPO recently, and we saw -- it seemed to us anyway a lot more commentary by some of the other packaging providers around direct printing on secondary packaging, which obviously if that really took off and it was scalable, would have some threat -- present some threat to labeling and pressure-sensitive materials. Mitch, what are you seeing in that regard? Are you seeing a little bit more activity there from competing technologies? Are you not -- would you agree with our perception that whether or not it's a threat, you're seeing a little more activity from competing materials and -- competing technology, I should say. And then similarly, it comes up periodically. Are you seeing any increased attempts by brand owners and retailers to not necessarily go down the RFID path, but use other technologies to track products through supply chain without having RFID [indiscernible] revision systems or other things like that?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, George. Yes, so specifically, as far as other labeling technologies and commenting on direct print, we've actually been engaging with a number of firms on the direct print front for a number of years now. So we have seen some activity here. The te
componenttext:
Thanks, George. Yes, so specifically, as far as other labeling technologies and commenting on direct print, we've actually been engaging with a number of firms on the direct print front for a number of years now. So we have seen some activity here. The technology, what we see as far as the economics of it, they're still pretty far ways off. So we're actively engaged. I think a number of people are playing with it and working through, but it's really going to be in small volumes premium side of the industry.
As far as the use of other technologies to attract products, we've been consistent in saying when we think about the Internet of Things and everything physical having a digital twin and digital life, we said RFID is one of a number of enabling technologies. And there's a number of areas where a wireless radio base connection will be required, others where you maybe have more clear line of sight, less SKU complexity and so forth, you can be using other technologies. So we think there's going to be a complement of technologies that enable that future overall. So that's not -- we're working with a number of those companies and well aware of that and see this is actually space where multiple technologies will prosper.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Mr. Butier, there are no further questions at this time. I will now turn the call back to you for any closing remarks.
componenttext: Mr. Butier, there are no further questions at this time. I will now turn the call back to you for any closing remarks.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thank you, everybody, for joining. Overall, another solid quarter. We're confident in achieving our long-term targets, which once again reflects the resilience of our industry-leading market positions, the strategic foundations we've laid and
componenttext:
Okay. Well, thank you, everybody, for joining. Overall, another solid quarter. We're confident in achieving our long-term targets, which once again reflects the resilience of our industry-leading market positions, the strategic foundations we've laid and our agile and talented workforce.
Thank you.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2019
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude the conference call for today. We thank you for your participation and ask that you please disconnect your lines.
componenttext:

We thank you for your participation and ask that you please disconnect your lines.
